comment: FRIED CHICKEN
steps: In a bowl, combine garlic, soy sauce, calamansi juice, salt, black pepper, and water.
Marinate the chicken pieces in the mixture for at least 1 hour, preferably overnight in the fridge.
In a separate bowl, mix flour and cornstarch.
Remove chicken from marinade and dredge each piece in the flour mixture until fully coated.
Heat cooking oil in a deep pan or wok over medium-high heat.
Deep fry the chicken pieces until golden brown and cooked through, about 10-15 minutes depending on size.
Remove chicken and drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve hot with your favorite dipping sauce.

comment: CALDERETA
steps: Heat oil in a pot and sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add beef chunks and cook until browned on all sides.
Add tomato sauce and liver spread. Stir well.
Pour in enough water to cover the meat. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat.
Simmer covered for 1.5-2 hours or until meat is tender.
Add potatoes and carrots. Cook until vegetables are tender.
Add bell peppers and green peas. Cook for another 5 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: ADOBO - the most iconic Filipino dish
steps: In a pot, combine chicken/pork, soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, bay leaves, and peppercorns.
Bring to a boil without stirring.
Lower heat and simmer for 30 minutes or until meat is tender.
Add water if needed and continue cooking until sauce thickens.
Serve hot with rice.

comment: SINIGANG
steps: Bring water to a boil in a pot.
Add onions and tomatoes, simmer for 2 minutes.
Add pork and cook until tender (about 30 minutes).
Add tamarind mix or fresh tamarind extract.
Add vegetables starting with the most firm (radish first, then string beans).
Add kangkong last and cook until just wilted.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with rice and fish sauce on the side.

comment: LECHON - crispy roasted whole pork
steps: Clean and prepare the pig thoroughly.
Make several deep incisions in the belly cavity.
Rub the cavity generously with salt, pepper, and crushed garlic.
Stuff with lemongrass stalks.
Sew up the cavity and truss the pig.
Roast on a spit over hot coals for 4-5 hours, rotating constantly.
Baste with oil during roasting to achieve crispy skin.
Let rest before chopping.
Serve with liver sauce.

comment: KARE-KARE - rich peanut stew
steps: Boil oxtail in water with salt until tender (about 2-3 hours). Reserve the broth.
In a separate pot, sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
Add the tenderized oxtail and cook for 2-3 minutes.
Add peanut butter and stir until well combined.
Pour in reserved broth, bring to a boil, then reduce heat to simmer.
Add ground rice to thicken the sauce, stirring constantly.
Add eggplant, banana blossom, and string beans. Cook until vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with bagoong (shrimp paste) on the side and steamed rice.

comment: PANCIT CANTON - Filipino stir-fried noodles
steps: Heat oil in a wok or large pan. Sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
Add chicken/pork and shrimp (if using). Cook until meat changes color.
Add carrots and other vegetables. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes.
Add noodles and soy sauce. Toss until well combined.
Add a little water if needed and cook until noodles are tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with calamansi on the side.

comment: PANCIT MALABON - thick noodles with seafood sauce
steps: Cook noodles according to package instructions. Set aside.
Heat annatto oil in a pan. Sauté garlic until fragrant.
Add shrimp and cook until pink.
Add smoked fish flakes and stir.
Add cooked noodles and toss until well coated with the orange oil.
Top with chopped eggs and crushed chicharon.
Serve hot with calamansi.

comment: PANCIT PALABOK - savory orange noodle dish
steps: Cook noodles according to package instructions. Set aside.
In a pan, cook ground pork until browned.
Add shrimp and cook until pink.
Make sauce by combining annatto powder with fish sauce and water.
Pour sauce over noodles.
Top with boiled eggs, chicharon, and remaining ingredients.
Serve hot with calamansi wedges.

comment: HALO-HALO - Filipino shaved ice dessert
steps: In a tall glass, layer sweetened beans, nata de coco, and kaong.
Add jackfruit strips and ube halaya.
Fill glass with shaved ice.
Pour evaporated milk over ice.
Top with leche flan slice.
Sprinkle with pinipig or cornflakes.
Serve immediately with a long spoon.

comment: LAING - spicy coconut gabi leaves dish
steps: In a pot, combine coconut milk, garlic, onion, and ginger.
Bring to a simmer over medium heat.
Add dried fish/shrimp if using.
Layer dried taro leaves on top (do not stir).
Pour coconut cream and add chili if using.
Simmer covered for 30-40 minutes or until leaves are tender.
Season with salt and pepper.
Gently stir before serving.

comment: LUMPIANG SHANGHAI - crispy fried meat spring rolls
steps: Mix ground pork, carrots, onion, garlic, and seasonings.
Place a portion of filling on each wrapper.
Roll tightly, sealing edges with water.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Fry lumpia until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with sweet chili sauce.

comment: LUMPIANG SARIWA - fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce
steps: Sauté garlic and onions, add vegetables and tofu.
Cook until vegetables are tender-crisp.
Season with salt and pepper.
Let filling cool.
Place lettuce leaf on lumpia wrapper.
Add filling and roll tightly.
Serve with peanut sauce.

comment: BISTEK TAGALOG - Filipino beef steak with soy and calamansi
steps: Marinate beef in soy sauce and calamansi juice for 30 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan. Cook beef until browned.
Remove beef and set aside.
In the same pan, cook onion rings until soft.
Return beef to pan and add remaining marinade.
Simmer until sauce is reduced.
Serve hot with rice.

comment: DINUGUAN - savory pork blood stew
steps: Sauté garlic and onion in oil.
Add pork and cook until browned.
Pour in vinegar and simmer without stirring.
Add pork blood, stirring constantly to prevent curdling.
Add bay leaf and chili peppers if using.
Simmer until sauce thickens.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with puto (rice cakes).

comment: BIBINGKA - traditional rice cake
steps: Line a cake pan or bibingka mold with banana leaves.
Mix rice flour, sugar, and baking powder in a bowl.
In another bowl, beat eggs then add coconut milk.
Combine wet and dry ingredients, mix until smooth.
Pour batter into lined pan.
Top with salted egg slices and cheese if using.
Bake at 375°F for 20-25 minutes until golden brown.
Brush with butter and serve warm.

comment: PINAKBET - mixed vegetable stew with bagoong
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic and onions until fragrant.
Add tomatoes and cook until softened.
Add bagoong and stir to combine.
Add squash and cook for 5 minutes.
Add remaining vegetables except for bitter melon.
Add bitter melon last and cook until all vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with rice.

comment: LONGGANISA - sweet or garlicky Filipino sausage
steps: Mix ground pork with all seasonings until well combined.
If using casings, stuff the mixture into them.
If making skinless longganisa, form into small logs.
Refrigerate overnight to develop flavors.
To cook, place in a pan with a little water.
Let water evaporate then fry in its own oil until browned.
Serve with garlic rice and fried egg.

comment: BULALO - beef marrow bone soup
steps: In a large pot, bring water to boil with beef shanks.
Simmer for 2-3 hours or until meat is tender.
Add corn and cook for 10 minutes.
Add potatoes and cook until tender.
Add cabbage and cook until just wilted.
Season with fish sauce and pepper.
Serve hot in bowls with rice on the side.

comment: ARROZ CALDO - Filipino rice porridge
steps: Sauté ginger, garlic, and onion until fragrant.
Add chicken pieces and cook until lightly browned.
Add rice and stir to coat with oil.
Pour in water or chicken broth and bring to boil.
Reduce heat and simmer until rice is very soft and porridge-like.
Season with fish sauce and pepper.
Top with toasted garlic, green onions, and egg.
Serve hot with calamansi.

comment: TOCINO - sweet cured pork
steps: In a bowl, combine sugar, salt, garlic, anise wine or pineapple juice, and red food coloring (if using).
Add the pork slices and mix thoroughly to coat evenly.
Transfer to a container, cover, and refrigerate for at least 2–3 days to cure.
To cook, place cured pork in a pan with a little water.
Let the water evaporate, then add oil and fry until meat is caramelized and tender.
Serve hot with garlic rice and egg for a classic breakfast.

comment: CHICKEN INASAL - grilled marinated chicken
steps: In a bowl, combine vinegar, calamansi juice, garlic, lemongrass, salt, and pepper.
Marinate the chicken in the mixture for at least 1 hour or overnight for better flavor.
Preheat your grill to medium heat.
Grill the chicken, turning occasionally, until cooked through and skin is charred and crispy.
Baste with annatto oil while grilling to enhance flavor and color.
Serve hot with steamed rice and dipping sauce if desired.

comment: MENUDO - Filipino pork stew with tomato sauce
steps: In a pan, sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add pork and cook until lightly browned.
Add liver and cook for a few minutes.
Pour in soy sauce, vinegar, and tomato sauce. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add potatoes and carrots. Cook until vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with rice.

comment: AFRITADA - Chicken or pork stew with tomato sauce and vegetables
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic and onion.
Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in tomato sauce and add bay leaves. Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add potatoes and carrots. Cook until tender.
Add bell peppers and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: AFRITADA - Chicken or pork stew with tomato sauce and vegetables
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté garlic and onion.
Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in tomato sauce and add bay leaves. Simmer for 15 minutes.
Add potatoes and carrots. Cook until tender.
Add bell peppers and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: INIHAW NA LIEMPO - Grilled marinated pork belly
steps: In a bowl, combine soy sauce, calamansi juice, garlic, brown sugar, salt, and pepper.
Add pork belly slices to the marinade and mix well. Marinate for at least 2 hours or overnight for best results.
Preheat your grill to medium heat.
Grill the pork belly until cooked through and slightly charred on both sides, basting with leftover marinade occasionally.
Slice into serving pieces and serve hot with rice and dipping sauce if desired.

comment: PAKSIW NA PATA - Pork hock stewed in vinegar and soy sauce with banana blossoms
steps: In a large pot, combine pork hock, soy sauce, vinegar, garlic, onion, peppercorns, bay leaves, and water.
Bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer until pork is tender (about 1.5 to 2 hours).
Add banana blossoms and brown sugar. Mix gently.
Simmer for another 10–15 minutes or until the sauce thickens slightly.
Adjust seasoning with salt if needed.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: PAKSIW NA LECHON - Leftover roast pig stewed in vinegar, liver sauce, and spices

ingredients.item: Lechon sauce (bottled or homemade liver sauce)

steps: In a pot, sauté garlic and onion until soft.
Add the lechon pieces and sauté briefly.
Pour in water, vinegar, soy sauce, and lechon sauce. Stir well.
Add bay leaves and brown sugar.
Bring to a boil without stirring, then lower heat and simmer for 30–40 minutes until meat is tender and sauce is thickened.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: PININYAHANG MANOK – Creamy chicken stew with pineapples and milk
steps: Heat oil in a pan. Sauté garlic and onion until fragrant.
Add chicken and cook until lightly browned.
Pour in pineapple juice and evaporated milk. Bring to a boil.
Add pineapple chunks, carrots, and simmer until chicken is tender.
Add bell pepper and cook for another 5 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: GINATAANG KALABASA AT SITAW – Squash and string beans cooked in coconut milk
steps: Heat oil in a pan. Sauté garlic, onion, and ginger until aromatic.
Add shrimp or dried fish if using and sauté briefly.
Pour in coconut milk and bring to a gentle boil.
Add kalabasa and simmer for 5 minutes.
Add sitaw and cook until both vegetables are tender.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot with steamed rice.

comment: GINISANG MUNGGO – Sauteed mung beans with pork and leafy greens
steps: Boil mung beans in water until soft (about 30–40 minutes). Set aside.
In a pan, heat oil and sauté garlic, onion, and tomato.
Add pork and cook until lightly browned.
Add boiled mung beans with its broth. Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add fish sauce and adjust seasoning with salt and pepper.
Stir in spinach or malunggay leaves. Simmer for 2 more minutes.
Serve hot with rice.

comment: TURON - Fried banana rolls with caramelized sugar and jackfruit
steps: Place a slice of banana and a few jackfruit strips on a spring roll wrapper.
Sprinkle brown sugar over the fruit.
Fold the wrapper tightly, sealing the edges with a little water.
Heat cooking oil in a pan over medium heat.
Fry the rolls until golden brown and caramelized, turning occasionally.
Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Serve warm as a sweet snack or dessert.

comment: LECHE FLAN - Filipino caramel custard dessert
steps: In a saucepan over low heat, melt sugar until it turns golden brown to make caramel.
Pour caramel into llanera or mold, swirling to coat the bottom evenly. Set aside to harden.
In a bowl, whisk egg yolks lightly.
Add condensed milk, evaporated milk, and vanilla extract. Mix well but avoid creating bubbles.
Pour the mixture through a strainer into the caramel-coated mold.
Cover with aluminum foil and steam over low heat for 30–40 minutes or until set. Alternatively, bake in a water bath at 350°F (175°C) for 45 minutes.
Let cool before refrigerating for at least 2 hours.
Unmold by running a knife around the edges and inverting onto a plate.
Serve chilled.
